skills.name: Interpret linear sections of real life graphs
Calculate mass where density and volume are in the appropriate units
Calculate volume where density and mass are in units that need to be changed
Convert rates of change of mass where both units need to be changed

explanations.A: If mass is density x volume, how would we rearrange to make density the subject?
explanations.B: If density is mass ÷ volume, how would we rearrange to make mass the subject?
explanations.C: Density measures how tightly the mass of an object is packed into the space it takes up. It is calculated by dividing the mass of the object by its volume, therefore Katie is correct. To find the mass of the object we can multiply both sides of the formula by the volume, which gives mass = density x volume, therefore Tom is also correct.
explanations.D: Density is the mass of an object per unit of volume. It is calculated by dividing an objects mass by its volume. If we know this, is Katie's formula correct? To check Tom's statement rearrange the density formula to make mass the subject.

explanations.A: Density is mass ÷ volume, how would we rearrange this to make volume the subject?
explanations.B: Density is mass ÷ volume, how would we rearrange this to make mass the subject?
explanations.C: The formula for density is mass ÷ volume. To make mass the subject we multiply both sides by the volume, which gives mass = density x volume, which is Tom's answer. To make volume the subject, we can rearrange Tom's answer and divide both sides by density, which gives volume = mass ÷ density, which is Katie's answer. Therefore they are both correct.
explanations.D: Density is mass ÷ volume. To check Tom's statement rearrange the formula to make mass the subject and to check Katie's statement rearrange to make volume the subject.

explanations.A: volume = mass ÷ density, so we have 2.1 ÷ 9. This would give us an answer in m³ so we need to multiply by 100³ (1000000) to get cm³
explanations.B: Not quite, cm³ are smaller than m³, so there should be more cm³ per m³.
explanations.C: Close, but while 100cm = 1m, to change from m³ to cm³ we should cube the converting multiplier.
explanations.D: Almost, but we're asked to convert our answer from m³ to cm³.

explanations.A: Almost, but we're asked to convert our answer from cm³ to mm³.
explanations.B: volume = mass ÷ density, so we have 1.5 ÷ 8. This would give us an answer in cm³ so we need to multiply by 10³ (1000) to get mm³
explanations.C: Not quite, mm³ are smaller than cm³, so there should be more mm³ per cm³.
explanations.D: Close, but while 10mm = 1cm, to change from cm³ to mm³ we should cube the converting multiplier.

explanations.A: You've recognised that 1 kg = 1000 g and 1 hour = 60 minutes, but kg/hour is calculated by dividing kilograms by time. What effect will dividing by time have when you convert to g/min?
explanations.B: Let's consider a value of 1 kg/hr. This tells us that in 1 hour, there is 1 kg; so we can write 1 hour = 1 kg. 1 kg = 1000g, so this means we have 1 hour = 1000g, which we have found by multiplying by 1000. We also know that 1 hour = 60 minutes, so we have 60 minutes = 1000g, to find 1 minute, we can divide by 60. This means our overall conversion calculation is to multiply by 1000, then divide by 60.
explanations.C: One of these operations is correct (well done!). Try thinking of a specific value, say 1 kg/hour, to help you decide how to get it completely right.
explanations.D: Kilogram per hour (or kg/hour) is calculated by dividing kilograms by the time. A value of 1 kg/hour tells us that in 1 hour, there is 1 kg. Can you change the units here and then find out what happens in 1 minute?

explanations.A: One of these operations is correct (well done!). Try thinking of a specific value, say 1 g/min, to help you decide how to get it completely right.
explanations.B: Grams per minute (or g/min) is calculated by dividing grams by the time. A value of 1 g/min tells us that in 1 minute, there is 1 g. Can you change the units here and then find out what happens in 1 hour?
explanations.C: You've recognised that 1 kg = 1000 g and 1 hour = 60 minutes, but g/min is calculated by dividing grams by time. What effect will dividing by time have when you convert to kg/hour?
explanations.D: Let's consider a value of 1g/min. This tells us that in 1 minute, there is 1g; so we can write 1 min = 1g. 1000g = 1kg, so this means we have to divide by 1000 to change to kg: 1 min = 0.001kg. We also know that 1 hour = 60 minutes, so to convert to 1 hour, we multiply by 60: 60 mins = 0.001x60 kg= 0.06kg. This means our overall conversion calculation is to divide by 1000, then multiply by 60.

explanations.A: The volume of water is decreasing, so the plug has been pulled out
explanations.B: I think you are looking at the wrong part of the graph. When the taps are turned off, the volume of water will say the same, it won't decrease
explanations.C: Not quite. Look at the label of the y axis. It is not measuring temperature.
explanations.D: Not quite, when the bath is filling with water, the volume will increase.

explanations.A: Not quite. Look at the label of the y axis. It is not measuring temperature.
explanations.B: If sand is added, think about what will happen to the mass of the bucket - will it increase or decrease?
explanations.C: When sand is tipped out, the mass of the bucket will decrease, which we can see by the negative slope.
explanations.D: Not quite. When the bucket is full, the mass will remain constant.

explanations.A: Not quite, the volume of water flowing is constant. A curve shows changes over time.
explanations.B: When water flows at a constant rate, the graph will be linear (straight line)
explanations.C: Not quite! Only one person is correct. A constant rate means the volume of water flowing is not changing
explanations.D: Not quite, one person is actually correct. A constant rate means the volume of water flowing is not changing

explanations.A: Tom's graph shows the mass is decreasing over time. It is a straight line which represents a constant gradient, so a constant rate. Katie's graph shows that the mass stays the same; it is not changing at all.
explanations.B: Not quite, Katie's graph shows the mass stays the same, so there is no change in the mass.
explanations.C: Not quite, only one graph shows a change in mass over time. Look at the y axis. Is the mass changing in both graphs?
explanations.D: Not quite! One of them is correct. Think about how the graph would look if the mass was decreasing at a constant rate
